content: The "Investment Tax Simplification Act of 2005" is also known as the Act. It includes a permanent reduction in capital gains rates for individuals and corporations. The "Investment Tax Simplification Act of 2005" repeals the sunset of reduction in capital gains rates for individuals and further reduces and simplifies capital gains rates for individuals. It amends section 1(h) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to limit the tax imposed on net capital gains for any taxable year. The "Investment Tax Simplification Act of 2005" limits the tax on net capital gains for individuals by calculating the amount based on taxable income and at rates below 25 percent. The maximum rate of tax on net capital gain of noncorporate taxpayers is also determined based on the taxable excess reduced by the net capital gain. The "Investment Tax Simplification Act of 2005" limits the tax on net capital gains for individuals based on taxable income and rates below 25 percent. Subsection (h) of section 1 of the Code is amended by redesignating paragraphs and making conforming amendments to various sections. The Investment Tax Simplification Act of 2005 reduces the capital gains rate for corporations from 35 percent to 15 percent. Additionally, amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to adjust tax rates on net capital gains for individuals. The Investment Tax Simplification Act of 2005 reduces the capital gains rate for corporations from 35 percent to 15 percent. Technical amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to adjust tax rates on net capital gains for individuals. The Merchant Marine Act, 1936 is amended to remove a specific percentage. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act, with a specific withholding amendment applying to amounts paid after the enactment date.
